definitions.definition: the state of no longer having something or as much of something; the process that leads to this

examples.text: I want to report the loss of a package.
Insure your instrument against **loss or damage**.
**weight loss**
**hearing/memory loss**
We can help people with sight loss lead full and independent lives.
The closure of the factory will lead to a number of **job losses**.
When she died I was filled with a **sense of loss**.
He **suffered a loss** of confidence.
loss of earnings/income *(= the money you do not earn because you are prevented from working)*
The **loss of her job** was a terrible blow.
He suffered a significant loss of hearing after the operation.
The knife hit an artery, causing significant blood loss.
She could have died from shock or loss of blood.
They form a barrier to prevent water loss.
a gradual loss of hope
loss of appetite
the dramatic loss of farmland to urban growth

definitions.definition: money that has been lost by a business or an organization

examples.text: The company has announced **net losses** of $1.5 million.
The banks **incurred **huge **losses**.
We **made a loss** on *(= lost money on)* the deal.
It took the company five years to recoup its losses.
No bank would be willing to underwrite such a loss.
The business sustained losses of €20 million.
The company took a big loss of 28%.
The fund may not be large enough to absorb these losses.
We can offset the loss against next year's budget.
He is **mourning the loss** of his wife.
the **tragic loss** of a child
Enemy troops suffered **heavy losses**.
The drought caused widespread **loss of life**.
Our country had sustained a tremendous loss of innocent life.
The loss of his wife was a great blow to him.
The family has suffered a terrible loss.
the devastating losses of the war

definitions.definition: the disadvantage that is caused when somebody leaves, or when a useful or valuable object is taken away; a person who causes a disadvantage by leaving

examples.text: Her departure is a **big loss** to the school.
She will be a **great loss** to the company.
She wouldn't be able to attend the lecture, which was no great loss.
His death is a sad loss to all who knew him.
His passing is a tremendous loss for all of us.
Her death at such a young age was a terrible loss to the music world.

definitions.definition: a failure to win a contest

examples.text: Brazil’s 2–1 loss to Argentina

definitions.definition: not knowing what to say or do

examples.text: His comments left me **at a loss for words**.
I'm at a loss what to do next.
We are at a loss to understand his actions.

definitions.definition: in a way that loses you money

examples.text: We are now operating at a loss.

definitions.definition: used to say that if somebody chooses not to do something, they will not obtain a benefit they could have had

examples.text: If people can't appreciate how great this film is, it's their loss.
I can see you don't trust me. Well, that's your loss

definitions.definition: to stop doing something that is not successful before the situation becomes even worse

examples.text: I decided to cut my losses and move back to England.
He decided to cut his losses and sell the shares before they sank further.

definitions.definition: the state of being less respected by other people or looking stupid because of something you have done

examples.text: Failure to pass the exams means a massive loss of face for the students and their parents.

wordOrigin: Old English los ‘destruction’, of Germanic origin; related to Old Norse los ‘breaking up of the ranks of an army’ and loose; later probably a back-formation from lost, past participle of lose.
